**[Orange DAO](https://orangedao.xyz/), a crypto collective created by Y Combinator alumni for backing Web3 startups, is excited to announce that it is allocating part of its treasury to [Cega](http://cega.fi), defi's first exotic options protocol in Solana.**

The first product of OrangeDAO was our fund to back web3 startups but now we want to support these exciting new protocols we invest in by using our treasury to become early users of their products.Â 

We believe in our vision so that is why we are deciding to put our money where our mouth is by creating our defi fund to allocate treasuries in founders that are building great things.

# Whatâ€™s Cega?

Cega is defi's first exotic options protocol in Solana. Founded by [Arisa Toyosaki](https://www.linkedin.com/in/toyosaki/)(google/bitcoin.com), [Winston Zhang](https://www.linkedin.com/in/winstonzhang/) (YC), [Victor Zhang](https://www.linkedin.com/in/zhangvictorz/) (YC/Tesla) and [Felicia Chen](https://www.linkedin.com/in/feliciachen0/)(Anduril/Apple), a rockstar team. Their goal is to create high-yielding products with protection in mind for every person's financial security.

Their inaugural exotic options product is the Fixed Coupon Note. Fixed coupon notes (FCN) are a type of exotic option structured product that has both equity option and bond-like characteristics. You can learn more about their product [here](https://cega.gitbook.io/cega/products/overview/fcn/what-are-fixed-coupon-notes-fcn)Â 

Their [product](http://cega.fi) has 3 yield offerings.

![Cega's different yield pools](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Pk9fj7ENacKcl995cFWqt.png?height=1048&width=2626)

They just launched a couple days ago and already have $30M+ in TVL. The team is very clear about the risks and have different levels of APY depending on what you are comfortable with.Â 

# Allocating OrangeDAOâ€™s treasury

We created a strategy/defi team that increases the yield the treasury of the DAO in a stable and secure way and also supports the protocols we invest in.Â 

As a macro strategy for our treasury, we have a combination of different levels of risk going from Aave protocol to exotic options.Â 

One of the frameworks we use to analyze these opportunities is the following:

* Who is the team behind this?
* Is this audited?
* Do we understand the business risks behind the protocol?
* TotalValueLocked

Cega was clearly a superb choice and decided to allocate part of our treasury in a combination of their different baskets.

We are looking for more yield opportunities, if you are building something please let us know at orlando@orangedao.xyz , alex@orangedao.xyz .

title: â˜„ï¸ An Intro to Balancer Protocol
body:
# 

# What are AMMs ?

Automated market makers (AMMs) are smart contracts that enable automated management of crowdsourced liquidity pools (LP), providing tradeable tokens to decentralized exchanges (DEX). AMMs are an important primitive in DeFi, as anyone can deposit their own tokens in an AMM LP, receiving a share of trading fees and the LP tokens in return.

How do AAMs differ from traditional finance? In the traditional trading model, buyers and sellers use something called an *order book*, where they write down what they want to trade in a huge list with everyoneâ€™s trades. The behavior of the buyers and sellers controls the market rates in the order book.

AMMs do not rely on humans to manage trades, which are controlled directly by algorithms. An AMM replaces the buy and sell orders in an order book market with a liquidity pool of two assets, both valued relative to each other. As one asset is traded for the other, the relative prices of the two assets shift, and the new market rate for both is re-calculated.Â 

The majority of AMMs use the *constant mean market maker equation *(also known as the constant product equation) to define how liquidity pools behave:

```
Balance of token A * Balance of token B = Constant product
```

For example, in a pool with 2,000,000 tokens A and 1,000 tokens B, the constant product is 2,000,000,000. This inverse correlation then determines the trading price of the assets at any moment, as the price of one token increases when the price of the second token decreases:

```
Market price for token A = Balance of token / Balance ofÂ  token A
```

The price curve is often utilized as a way to visualize this relation:

To find the swap price for the assets in a given pool (i.e., the amount of **token A** received when you exchange a certain quantity of **token B**), we calculate the balances for each token that are needed in the pool to keep the constant product unchanged after the swap:

```
Balance of token A - Quantity of token A received = (Constant product) / (Balance of token B + Quantity of token B paid)
```

The amount of **token A** received from this swap conveys the â€œbuy priceâ€, and itâ€™s calculated from the relation above:

```
Quantity of token A received = (Balance of token A * Quantity of token BÂ  paid) / (Balance of token BÂ  +Â  Quantity of token B paid)
```


---

## Enter Balancer

Launched in 2018, Balancer introduced a protocol for configurable liquidity on the Ethereum blockchain and other EVM-compatible systems. With Balancer, users are able to create liquidity pools with up to eight different ERC-20 tokens, in any ratio. These pools can be thought of as automatically *rebalancing portfolios*, providing traders with what can be called a *decentralized index fund.*Â 

Balancer routes several pools together, allowing easy trades from one token in one pool to any other token in another pool. These multi-asset pools work using what is called *weighted math*, designed to allow swaps between any asset whether or not they have a price correlation. Balancer's price equation is a generalization of the constant product equation, accounting for multi-tokens and weightings that are not evenly split, so that prices are determined by the poolsâ€™ balances and weights.

Balancerâ€™s core smart contract is called [â€œThe Vault''](https://docs.balancer.fi/products/the-vault), and it controls and holds all tokens in each of the Balancer pools. The Vaultâ€™s architecture separates the *token accounting and management* from the *pool logic*, simplifying the poolsâ€™ contracts. In this architecture, [Balancerâ€™s Protocol Swap Fees](https://docs.balancer.fi/concepts/fees) are the percentage of swap fees collected by pools defined on a contract named [ProtocolFeesCollector.sol](https://etherscan.io/address/0xce88686553686DA562CE7Cea497CE749DA109f9F#readContract). These fees include flash loan fees, and they are adjusted through governance by the Balancerâ€™s DAO.Â 


---

## Balancerâ€™s Flash Loan

Flash Loans are special smart contract operations that allow the borrowing of any available amount of assets (up to the total liquidity) without collateral. This is possible as long as the liquidity plus interests are returned within one block transaction. If the borrower is unable to repay the loan, the entire transaction is simply reverted. 

A common use of flash loans is on arbitrage algorithms, searching for profit by trading an asset on a first DEX and then getting back the asset plus gains on other DEXs.Â 

In the context of Balancer, a trader could borrow any amount of tokens available on The Vault to use on a flash loan. The logic for these types of transactions is specified in the [FlashLoans.sol](https://etherscan.io/address/0xBA12222222228d8Ba445958a75a0704d566BF2C8#code#F5#L20) contract, more specifically in the flashLoan function:

1\. This function starts with straightforward initializations, ensuring that the length of the token array and the amount array match, and assigning the zero address to the previousToken variable (to ensure the tokens are sorted and unique):

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/UREh_nf-SFXdGe8LCFFVz.png?height=472&width=1136)

2\. The first loop over the tokensâ€™ array is used to record the pre-balance of each token, calculate the loan fees, and transfer each amount of token to the receiver. Note the callback function on receiver, receiveFlashLoan, right after the loop:

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/cpvblxToE4608coCEetW0.png?height=458&width=1496)

3\. The second loop checks whether each tokenâ€™s balance is equal or larger than their previous balance, then add any balance surplus as a fee in the receivedFeeAmount variable:

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/vx7_fibJIg6qIV5lZv2Yi.png?height=322&width=1436)

4\. This fee is then transferred to ProtocolFeesCollector:

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/dN_t1A4G-tuxZQYwpdRyp.png?height=106&width=622)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/hTavNmYO706f6ctLALqKV.png?height=194&width=1084)


---

# What are AMMs ?

Automated market makers (AMMs) are smart contracts that enable automated management of crowdsourced liquidity pools (LP), providing tradeable tokens to decentralized exchanges (DEX). AMMs are an important primitive in DeFi, as anyone can deposit their own tokens in an AMM LP, receiving a share of trading fees and the LP tokens in return.

How do AAMs differ from traditional finance? In the traditional trading model, buyers and sellers use something called an *order book*, where they write down what they want to trade in a huge list with everyoneâ€™s trades. The behavior of the buyers and sellers controls the market rates in the order book.

AMMs do not rely on humans to manage trades, which are controlled directly by algorithms. An AMM replaces the buy and sell orders in an order book market with a liquidity pool of two assets, both valued relative to each other. As one asset is traded for the other, the relative prices of the two assets shift, and the new market rate for both is re-calculated.Â 

The majority of AMMs use the *constant mean market maker equation *(also known as the constant product equation) to define how liquidity pools behave:

```
Balance of token A * Balance of token B = Constant product
```

For example, in a pool with 2,000,000 tokens A and 1,000 tokens B, the constant product is 2,000,000,000. This inverse correlation then determines the trading price of the assets at any moment, as the price of one token increases when the price of the second token decreases:

```
Market price for token A = Balance of token / Balance ofÂ  token A
```

The price curve is often utilized as a way to visualize this relation:

To find the swap price for the assets in a given pool (i.e., the amount of **token A** received when you exchange a certain quantity of **token B**), we calculate the balances for each token that are needed in the pool to keep the constant product unchanged after the swap:

```
Balance of token A - Quantity of token A received = (Constant product) / (Balance of token B + Quantity of token B paid)
```

The amount of **token A** received from this swap conveys the â€œbuy priceâ€, and itâ€™s calculated from the relation above:

```
Quantity of token A received = (Balance of token A * Quantity of token BÂ  paid) / (Balance of token BÂ  +Â  Quantity of token B paid)
```


---

## Enter Balancer

Launched in 2018, Balancer introduced a protocol for configurable liquidity on the Ethereum blockchain and other EVM-compatible systems. With Balancer, users are able to create liquidity pools with up to eight different ERC-20 tokens, in any ratio. These pools can be thought of as automatically *rebalancing portfolios*, providing traders with what can be called a *decentralized index fund.*Â 

Balancer routes several pools together, allowing easy trades from one token in one pool to any other token in another pool. These multi-asset pools work using what is called *weighted math*, designed to allow swaps between any asset whether or not they have a price correlation. Balancer's price equation is a generalization of the constant product equation, accounting for multi-tokens and weightings that are not evenly split, so that prices are determined by the poolsâ€™ balances and weights.

Balancerâ€™s core smart contract is called [â€œThe Vault''](https://docs.balancer.fi/products/the-vault), and it controls and holds all tokens in each of the Balancer pools. The Vaultâ€™s architecture separates the *token accounting and management* from the *pool logic*, simplifying the poolsâ€™ contracts. In this architecture, [Balancerâ€™s Protocol Swap Fees](https://docs.balancer.fi/concepts/fees) are the percentage of swap fees collected by pools defined on a contract named [ProtocolFeesCollector.sol](https://etherscan.io/address/0xce88686553686DA562CE7Cea497CE749DA109f9F#readContract). These fees include flash loan fees, and they are adjusted through governance by the Balancerâ€™s DAO.Â 


---

## Balancerâ€™s Flash Loan

Flash Loans are special smart contract operations that allow the borrowing of any available amount of assets (up to the total liquidity) without collateral. This is possible as long as the liquidity plus interests are returned within one block transaction. If the borrower is unable to repay the loan, the entire transaction is simply reverted. 

A common use of flash loans is on arbitrage algorithms, searching for profit by trading an asset on a first DEX and then getting back the asset plus gains on other DEXs.Â 

In the context of Balancer, a trader could borrow any amount of tokens available on The Vault to use on a flash loan. The logic for these types of transactions is specified in the [FlashLoans.sol](https://etherscan.io/address/0xBA12222222228d8Ba445958a75a0704d566BF2C8#code#F5#L20) contract, more specifically in the flashLoan function:

1\. This function starts with straightforward initializations, ensuring that the length of the token array and the amount array match, and assigning the zero address to the previousToken variable (to ensure the tokens are sorted and unique):

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/UREh_nf-SFXdGe8LCFFVz.png?height=472&width=1136)

2\. The first loop over the tokensâ€™ array is used to record the pre-balance of each token, calculate the loan fees, and transfer each amount of token to the receiver. Note the callback function on receiver, receiveFlashLoan, right after the loop:

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/cpvblxToE4608coCEetW0.png?height=458&width=1496)

3\. The second loop checks whether each tokenâ€™s balance is equal or larger than their previous balance, then add any balance surplus as a fee in the receivedFeeAmount variable:

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/vx7_fibJIg6qIV5lZv2Yi.png?height=322&width=1436)

4\. This fee is then transferred to ProtocolFeesCollector:

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/dN_t1A4G-tuxZQYwpdRyp.png?height=106&width=622)

title: Governance Recap #1: Driving Long-Term Growth for Aura
body:
The past week has seen a whirlwind of temperature checks and draft proposals from core contributors, representatives of DAOs, and community members focused on driving long-term sustainability and growth for Aura. These proposals remain in draft stage, though will be taken to vote in this [next vlAURA voting cycle](https://snapshot.org/#/aurafinance.eth), starting Thursday July 21st.

This is the first of (hopefully) many somewhat-regular governance recaps, summarizing what members of the Aura DAO are thinking and will be bringing to vote in the coming voting cycles.

## \[AIP-2\]: auraBAL Reward Reallocation

Core contributors PhiJFry and 0xButterfield [are suggesting](https://forum.aura.finance/t/aip-2-aurabal-reward-reallocation/82/7) the redirection of rewards from the existing auraBAL liquidity pool to the new auraBAL gauge, recently approved by Balancer governance, along with Hidden Hand bribes for that same gauge. These rewards represent 10% of the total AURA supply, distributed over five years.

Butterfield and PhijFry suggest the proposal will consolidate and potentially deepen auraBAL liquidity, creating a better user experience for system participants.

The proposal has passed by the DAO and will be executed some time over the next day as of this articleâ€™s publishing.

## \[AIP-3\] Increasing AURA Float and Liquidity, while Building DAO Runway

Independent investor SmallCapScientist and BadgerDAO contributor Tritium, both of which have been advocates for Aura since its launch, [are supportive of](https://forum.aura.finance/t/aip-3-increasing-aura-float-and-liquidity-while-building-dao-runway/92/14) building a longer runway for the DAO.

The Aura DAO treasury currently has $400,000 of reserve assets, half of which are earmarked exclusively for an ImmuneFi bounty payout. A large tranche of leftover tokens from initial liquidity distribution and the airdrop, totaling 2,800,000 AURA, have also been returned to the treasury, creating a purported liquidity crisis where not enough AURA is circulating for DAOs and other participants to properly accumulate.

SmallCap and Tritium say 350,000 AURA should be diversified into USDC for the DAO to extend its runway, inject more AURA float into the market, and give a way for market participants to more easily acquire AURA

## \[AIP-4\] Boost protocol fee to auraBAL to increase Auraâ€™s veBAL intake

Core contributor Butterfield is [proposing](https://forum.aura.finance/t/aip-4-boost-protocol-fee-to-aurabal-to-increase-aura-s-vebal-intake/100/9) to increase the protocol fees routed toward the auraBAL staking pool to entice more \[80/20 BAL/ETH BPT\] deposits, and thus Auraâ€™s share of veBAL voting power. This fee increase will be funded by a general fee increase on BAL earned by the DAO, along with the BAL directed toward vlAURA depositors. 

vlAURA depositors are being compensated by the introduction of Balancerâ€™s Core Pools proposal, which routed significant fees that would have previously gone to auraBAL holders to vlAURA holders. It is also argued that the long-term growth in Auraâ€™s veBAL share will lead to greater system revenue overall, benefiting AURA.

## \[Temperature Check\] Aura Foundation Funding Proposal

Aura Foundation Advisory Committee member 0xsmtg is [requesting](https://forum.aura.finance/t/temperature-check-aura-foundation-funding-proposal/104) a grant of 300,000 AURA to cover the costs of establishing and operating the Foundation for 2022 and 2023.

The Foundation is a Cayman Islands entity that will be responsible for engaging in legal contracts on behalf of the DAO. The Foundation will also has a subsidiary company in the BVI responsible for hosting the Aura front-end, developing the Aura blockchain application, and maintaining social media accounts and general operations.

## \[Temperature Check\] TribeDAO airdrop redirection bug fix

Core contributor Butterfield is [petitioning](https://forum.aura.finance/t/temperature-check-tribedao-airdrop-redirection-bug-fix/106) for a redirection of AURA from the treasury to an address operated by Tribe DAO.

Tribe contacted Aura with redirection requests for the initial airdrop to Balancer, Convex, and LobsterDAO community members, though due to a small bug with the token allocation script (limited in scope to this allocation alone), the redirection was only partially applied, leaving 10.6k AURA un-claimable by the DAO.

This proposal would lock the AURA from the treasury on behalf of an address operated by Tribe.

## \[Temperature Check\] Deepening AURA/ETH Liquidity With Hidden Hand Bribes From DAO

Redacted founder 0xSami [believes](https://forum.aura.finance/t/temperature-check-tribedao-airdrop-redirection-bug-fix/106) Aura will benefit from deeper liquidity to allow for market participants to more easily scale in and out of the ecosystem. With AURA market depth still below that of other top DeFi coins, AURA from the treasury, initially slated to be used as liquidity, can be redirected to Hidden Hand to simultaneously deepen liquidity while rewarding committed market participants.

This proposal should also help to bootstrap a bribing ecosystem on Hidden Hand by making it more competitive for market participants seeking liquidity.

## What Can You Do?

Stakeholders interested in these proposals should join the conversation [in Discord](https://t.co/SExgX0nbty) and on our [forum](https://forum.aura.finance/). These draft proposals should be live on [our Snapshot](https://snapshot.org/#/aurafinance.eth) later this week, starting Thursday, with voting ending on Sunday. Use your vlAURA to help determine the future of Aura.

If youâ€™re not interested in voting, please feel free to delegate your vlAURA voting power to an individual or DAO that is aligned with your views. You can do so on the [Aura applicationâ€™s â€œLockâ€ page](https://app.aura.finance/#/lock).

The future of Aura relies on stakeholders. Get involved today!

title: Governance Recap #1: Driving Long-Term Growth for Aura
body:
The past week has seen a whirlwind of temperature checks and draft proposals from core contributors, representatives of DAOs, and community members focused on driving long-term sustainability and growth for Aura. These proposals remain in draft stage, though will be taken to vote in this [next vlAURA voting cycle](https://snapshot.org/#/aurafinance.eth), starting Thursday July 21st.

This is the first of (hopefully) many somewhat-regular governance recaps, summarizing what members of the Aura DAO are thinking and will be bringing to vote in the coming voting cycles.

## \[AIP-2\]: auraBAL Reward Reallocation

Core contributors PhiJFry and 0xButterfield [are suggesting](https://forum.aura.finance/t/aip-2-aurabal-reward-reallocation/82/7) the redirection of rewards from the existing auraBAL liquidity pool to the new auraBAL gauge, recently approved by Balancer governance, along with Hidden Hand bribes for that same gauge. These rewards represent 10% of the total AURA supply, distributed over five years.

Butterfield and PhijFry suggest the proposal will consolidate and potentially deepen auraBAL liquidity, creating a better user experience for system participants.

The proposal has passed by the DAO and will be executed some time over the next day as of this articleâ€™s publishing.

## \[AIP-3\] Increasing AURA Float and Liquidity, while Building DAO Runway

Independent investor SmallCapScientist and BadgerDAO contributor Tritium, both of which have been advocates for Aura since its launch, [are supportive of](https://forum.aura.finance/t/aip-3-increasing-aura-float-and-liquidity-while-building-dao-runway/92/14) building a longer runway for the DAO.

The Aura DAO treasury currently has $400,000 of reserve assets, half of which are earmarked exclusively for an ImmuneFi bounty payout. A large tranche of leftover tokens from initial liquidity distribution and the airdrop, totaling 2,800,000 AURA, have also been returned to the treasury, creating a purported liquidity crisis where not enough AURA is circulating for DAOs and other participants to properly accumulate.

SmallCap and Tritium say 350,000 AURA should be diversified into USDC for the DAO to extend its runway, inject more AURA float into the market, and give a way for market participants to more easily acquire AURA

## \[AIP-4\] Boost protocol fee to auraBAL to increase Auraâ€™s veBAL intake

Core contributor Butterfield is [proposing](https://forum.aura.finance/t/aip-4-boost-protocol-fee-to-aurabal-to-increase-aura-s-vebal-intake/100/9) to increase the protocol fees routed toward the auraBAL staking pool to entice more \[80/20 BAL/ETH BPT\] deposits, and thus Auraâ€™s share of veBAL voting power. This fee increase will be funded by a general fee increase on BAL earned by the DAO, along with the BAL directed toward vlAURA depositors. 

vlAURA depositors are being compensated by the introduction of Balancerâ€™s Core Pools proposal, which routed significant fees that would have previously gone to auraBAL holders to vlAURA holders. It is also argued that the long-term growth in Auraâ€™s veBAL share will lead to greater system revenue overall, benefiting AURA.

## \[Temperature Check\] Aura Foundation Funding Proposal

Aura Foundation Advisory Committee member 0xsmtg is [requesting](https://forum.aura.finance/t/temperature-check-aura-foundation-funding-proposal/104) a grant of 300,000 AURA to cover the costs of establishing and operating the Foundation for 2022 and 2023.

The Foundation is a Cayman Islands entity that will be responsible for engaging in legal contracts on behalf of the DAO. The Foundation will also has a subsidiary company in the BVI responsible for hosting the Aura front-end, developing the Aura blockchain application, and maintaining social media accounts and general operations.

## \[Temperature Check\] TribeDAO airdrop redirection bug fix

Core contributor Butterfield is [petitioning](https://forum.aura.finance/t/temperature-check-tribedao-airdrop-redirection-bug-fix/106) for a redirection of AURA from the treasury to an address operated by Tribe DAO.

Tribe contacted Aura with redirection requests for the initial airdrop to Balancer, Convex, and LobsterDAO community members, though due to a small bug with the token allocation script (limited in scope to this allocation alone), the redirection was only partially applied, leaving 10.6k AURA un-claimable by the DAO.

This proposal would lock the AURA from the treasury on behalf of an address operated by Tribe.

## \[Temperature Check\] Deepening AURA/ETH Liquidity With Hidden Hand Bribes From DAO

Redacted founder 0xSami [believes](https://forum.aura.finance/t/temperature-check-tribedao-airdrop-redirection-bug-fix/106) Aura will benefit from deeper liquidity to allow for market participants to more easily scale in and out of the ecosystem. With AURA market depth still below that of other top DeFi coins, AURA from the treasury, initially slated to be used as liquidity, can be redirected to Hidden Hand to simultaneously deepen liquidity while rewarding committed market participants.

This proposal should also help to bootstrap a bribing ecosystem on Hidden Hand by making it more competitive for market participants seeking liquidity.

## What Can You Do?

Stakeholders interested in these proposals should join the conversation [in Discord](https://t.co/SExgX0nbty) and on our [forum](https://forum.aura.finance/). These draft proposals should be live on [our Snapshot](https://snapshot.org/#/aurafinance.eth) later this week, starting Thursday, with voting ending on Sunday. Use your vlAURA to help determine the future of Aura.

If youâ€™re not interested in voting, please feel free to delegate your vlAURA voting power to an individual or DAO that is aligned with your views. You can do so on the [Aura applicationâ€™s â€œLockâ€ page](https://app.aura.finance/#/lock).

The future of Aura relies on stakeholders. Get involved today!

title: Weeds and small fish
body:
![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/jDEqsCbvI3NLejbSbo7CH.png?height=266&width=456)

A small sea, quiet existence. The abundant sunshine makes the sea bluer, and the seaside is quite lush. They are aquatic plants that grow along the coast.

There is a water plant that he doesn't want to be in a group, and he always looks out to the sea alone and thinks. Imagine what's on the other side of the sea.

In the evening, he listened to the singing of the waves, hoping that the wind would blow his mind away and drift away into the distance. Suddenly, another song interrupted his fantasy.

"La la la la... la la..." A small fish swam here with bubbles and humming a song.

Xiaoyu found him, stopped, and asked him, "Shui Cao, why are you looking at the sea alone?"

He smiled and said, "Little fish, I was thinking about what the other side of the sea would look like."

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/qbNGgWVldv2JASyVKVuX6.png?height=270&width=397)

"Oh." Xiaoyu spit out a bubble, "Maybe it's still the sea, because the sea is very big."

"Little fish, I believe that there must be another scene on the other side of the sea." Waterweed said with infinite fascination.

Xiaoyu said: "Then when I grow up, I'll come and have a look."

The waves are dancing happily again.

A spring has passed, and the little fish has only grown a little. However, she fell in love with water plants.

Every afternoon, small fish dare to swim from the bottom of the sea to the surface. Swim to the side of the grass. Because of the harsh sun in the morning, the little fish was too small for his body to bear. But every now and then, she would slip up in disobedience at noon, spit at the water plants, and talk intimately for a while. It was not until the sun scalded the fish that she reluctantly swam back to the bottom of the sea.

Their love is helpless, the water grass can't give the little fish a hug, because he is not a water grass in the sea; the little fish can't give the water grass a kiss, because she is not a bird on the shore.

She could only look at him and smile and smile at him. Sing to him and pop a bubble. They talked about the other side of the sea together. The water plant said that there must be a lot of small fish there, and the small fish said that there must be countless water plants there.

One day, the grandfather of the big fish said to the little fish: "Your love has no results, you are not a water plant, and he is not a small fish."

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/ecqNK3sDyS9nQ80sBurZV.png?height=266&width=474)

Xiaoyu wagged his tail vigorously, "I don't care! I don't care!"

Grandpa Dayu sighed and continued: "I can use magic to restore your memory to eight seconds, you only love him for eight seconds."

Xiaoyu shouted: "No! Even if I become a fishbone, I will still love him, remember him!" Xiaoyu turned and swam away.

She swam to the side of the water plants, she did not speak. She was crying all the time. She knew that water plants could not see.

"Silly little fish, why are you crying?" Shui Cao asked distressedly.

Xiaoyu was surprised, "How did you know?"

Waterweed smiled proudly, "Fool, I stretched my roots into the sea and felt your tears. It's so warm."

The little fish burst into tears.

With the arrival of summer day by day, the sea water is getting hotter and hotter by the sun. Small fish are getting weaker and weaker due to frequent exposure to ultraviolet rays and immersion in warm seawater. The scales are also falling off.

The journey from the bottom of the sea to the surface of the sea is getting longer and longer, and the small fish are struggling more and more. Missing makes her crazy, she can't see him for a day. The summer sun makes the water plants grow taller and greener. Xiaoyu's eyes were full of green that fascinated her.

Xiaoyu heard that the parents of the aquatic plants wanted him to marry another aquatic plant in early autumn. She was crying hard on the bottom of the sea, and the fish passing by didn't even know she was crying. In this world, only water plants can feel the temperature of her crying. Xiaoyu burst out crying, and she cried all the water in her body.

At night, the little fish swam to the surface. Staring at the water plants madly. Both are speechless. They both understand the pain in each other's hearts. Only knowing is not annoying: "I know, I know..."

After the little fish left, the mood of the water plants was difficult to calm down for a long time. He couldn't forget Xiaoyu's desperate eyes and broken scales. He made a big decision: he wanted to find a way to pull out the roots, plunge into the sea, and be with the little fish. Whether doing so is life or death.

The next day, the sun was particularly strong. The aquatic plants had to crawl on the wetlands to avoid sunburning themselves. He wants to tell Xiaoyu his decision at night.

At dusk, the water plants straighten their bodies. Not far away, he seemed to see a small fish, motionless there.

Wave after wave of sea water patted the little fish ashore and stopped beside the aquatic plants.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/CoR8Qej4ah9tFqJQRK6sF.png?height=266&width=439)

Is it a small fish? ! Oh, no. It's the corpse of a small fish. Baked by the sun into small dried fish.

With tears in her eyes, the water grass leaned down and gently hugged the scarred, stiff little fish.

Grandpa Big Fish swam over and sighed. Take out a small conch and say that the last sentence of the small fish is preserved in it

title: What Is Web3?
body:
# What Is Web3?

`Web3 is a new evolution of the Internet based around the principles of decentralization. Web3 combines the rich and interactive digital experiences that exist today with infrastructure that offers users ownership and cryptographic guarantees.` 
 

Web3 has recently burst into the mainstream consciousness, with industry leaders across the traditional tech sector and blockchain ecosystem weighing in with a wide range of perspectives on the past and future of the Internet. 
  
 Before we dive in, a brief history of the term. 
  
 The term â€œWeb 3.0â€ was first used during the dotcom era by HTTP pioneer Tim Berners-Lee to describe an integrated communication framework in which Internet data is machine-readable across different applications and systemsâ€”a concept he also referred to as the Semantic Web. 
  
 Later, in his 2014 blog post [DApps: What Web 3.0 Looks Like](http://gavwood.com/dappsweb3.html), Ethereum Co-founder Gavin Wood repurposed Berners-Leeâ€™s expression, using it to refer to the ability of blockchain technology to define a â€œfundamentally different model for the interactions between partiesâ€ based on â€œa zero-trust interaction system.â€ 
  
 Woodâ€™s writing focused not on cryptocurrencies but on protocols and technologies, such as consensus engines and cryptography, that could facilitate a stronger social contract across the web. He later described the aim of Web3 as â€œLess trust, more truth.â€ 
  
 Now, the term is the subject of much debate, with both the tech giants of today and the vanguard of the blockchain industry continuing to reckon with Web3â€™s core propositions and protocols, and its implications for the trust models of the future. 
  
 In this deep dive, weâ€™ll define Web3 in relation to earlier iterations of the Internet, walk through the key technologies of the Web3 stack, and explore the current and future state of the Web3 landscape. 
  
 â€**A note on terminology:** Weâ€™ll use the term â€œWeb3â€ as distinct from â€œWeb 3.0â€, which is often associated with Berners-Leeâ€™s vision of the Semantic Web. 
 

## The Evolution of the Internet: From Web 1.0 to Web 2.0 to Web3

To truly grasp the meaning of Web3, itâ€™s important to understand the history of the Internet and how Web3 differs from the versions of the web that preceded it. 
 

### Web 1.0 (1994-2004)

Web 1.0 was the first iteration of the Internet weâ€™re familiar with today, emerging in 1994 and ending around 2004 with the rise of social media giants like Twitter and Facebook. While the general public came to learn about the Web 1.0 Internet around 1994, Web 1.0 actually started as a U.S. government program called ARPANET, or Advanced Research Projects Agency Network, in 1968. ARPANET began as a small network of military contractors and university professors who exchanged data with one another. 
 

![ARPANET circa 1967. Each node in this diagram was either a computer at a university such as UC Berkeley, Stanford, UCLA, Michigan, Carnegie Mellon, or MIT. (source)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/dq8hfK6hVBESyzGBjsWbJ.png?height=945&width=1088)

The Web 1.0 Internet was mostly a collection of static HTML pages and afforded users limited ability to interact with each other. Although Internet gateways such as America Online (AOL) and discussion forums such as Usenet permitted private chat and discussion boards, for most the Internet remained a space where few interactions or financial transactions took place. 
  
 

![Web 1.0 pizza ordering form. Pizza Hut was an innovative company in the Web 1.0 space because it introduced a website that customers could use to order pizza. Payments, however, had to be made in person. (source)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/ZwMnxGlhDFI7jl5AXf_NO.png?height=300&width=450)

Where interactions and financial transactions did take place, they were limited in scope because there was a lack of secure infrastructure for transferring money. One of the most innovative Web 1.0 companies in this respect was Pizza Hut, which in 1995 created an order form for its customers that they could use to place an order and pay in cash once this order was delivered. 
 

![Early commercial for America Online (AOL), one of the first Internet gateways. AOL sent CDs with their software and 10 free hours of use to millions of people. (source)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/RnQJc-Wmm-KOCBLGsrxUg.png?height=360&width=480)

 
 

Despite America Onlineâ€™s claim in a 1995 commercial that users could order flowers for their mom, buy tickets to a sports game, or write a research report on dinosaurs with AOL, exchanging money online required speaking with an operator since financial transactions were generally unsafe and had limited encryption. 
 

### Web 2.0 (2004-The Present)

The web evolved around 2004 as user demand for social interactions, music, video sharing, and financial transactions grew dramatically due to improved Internet speed, fiber optic infrastructure, and search engine improvements. 
 

![The MySpace page of Tom Anderson, co-founder of the early Web 2.0 company. Tom was your first contact when you signed up for a MySpace account. (source)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xI_Jlc5Nq3F6QC7i7LIpp.png?height=630&width=1200)

 
 

This demand for greater interactivity gave rise to many of todayâ€™s Internet institutions and companies. Social media platforms like Facebook, MySpace, and Twitter facilitated social interaction; data-sharing applications such as Napster met the demand for online music and video; Google provided an effective means for users to navigate the huge quantity of online information. Traditional institutions such as Bank of America met the demand for financial interactions and electronic fund transfers, enabled by new encryption standards such as 256-bit AES. 
  
 This new, more interactive Internet improved usersâ€™ experiences of the web tremendously by adding new functionality. But it also presented a tradeoff that continues to define our online lives to this day: To benefit from these new functionalities and interactions, users have to delegate a large quantity of information and responsibility to siloed third-party platforms, granting these centralized entities a considerable amount of power and influence in terms of data and content ownership. 
  
 This is, for the most part, how the Internet operates up until the present day. In the United States alone, Google, YouTube, Facebook, and Amazon combined [received 23.56 billion visits](https://www.semrush.com/blog/most-visited-websites/) in October 2021â€”roughly double the traffic of websites ranked 5-20. 
 

### Web3 (2008-The Future)

In 2008, Satoshi Nakamoto published the [Bitcoin whitepaper](https://bitcoin.org/bitcoin.pdf), which outlined the fundamentals of [blockchain technology](https://blog.chain.link/what-is-a-blockchain-and-how-can-it-impact-the-world/) and a peer-to-peer digital currency, setting a course to change the Web 2.0 paradigm. Bitcoin transformed how we think about digital transactions and provided the first secure means of exchanging money over the Internet that didnâ€™t require a trusted third party. â€œWhat is needed,â€ Satoshi wrote, â€œis an electronic payment system based on cryptographic proof instead of trust.â€ 
  
 It was not until the invention of [smart contracts](https://chain.link/education/smart-contracts) that a decentralized model of the Internet truly came into focus. If Bitcoin enabled secure peer-to-peer payments and smart contracts could expand this idea of programmable agreements to more advanced use casesâ€”insurance, gaming, identity management, supply chainsâ€”how would the nature of web experience and digital interaction evolve? By enabling users to directly and securely transact with one another, smart contracts created a fresh vision for an Internet that is fair, transparent, and powered by cryptographic truth. 
  
 Gavin Wood described this reimagined webâ€”Web3â€”as a â€œSecure Social Operating System.â€ 
  
 Put simply, Web3 is a decentralized vision of the Internet that aspires to create an entirely new system of contracts and change the way that individuals and institutions reach agreements. Web3 brings back the decentralized architecture of Web 1.0, the first version of the Internet, which was replete with user-hosted blogs and RSS feeds, and combines it with the rich, interactive experience of Web 2.0 web applications like social media platforms to provide a digital ecosystem where data is user-owned and transactions are backed by cryptographic guarantees. Rather than having to trust brand-based paper promises, users can rely on deterministic software logic to execute agreements exactly as programmed. 
 

![Interactions between content consumers and producers Web 1.0, 2.0, and Web3.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/t223qh0ZA6x1RD510UPvS.png?height=752&width=1600)

 
 

## The Core Elements of Web3: Blockchains, Cryptocurrency, Smart Contracts, and Oracles

Powering the Web3 model is a growing stack of decentralized technologies, such as blockchains, smart contracts, [oracles](https://chain.link/education/blockchain-oracles), crypto wallets, storage networks, and more. Below, we walk through some of the critical layers and componentry of the Web3 technology stack. 
 

### Blockchains

A [blockchain](https://blog.chain.link/what-is-a-blockchain-and-how-can-it-impact-the-world/) is a highly secure and decentralized network that allows people to store data, exchange value, and record transaction activity in a shared ledger that is not controlled by any central authority. Blockchain networks serve as the backbone of Web3, providing secure execution environments that allow for the creation, distribution, and trading of cryptocurrencies, as well as the development of programmable smart contracts. Blockchains are the settlement layer of Web3. 
 

### Cryptocurrency

Cryptocurrencies are digital tokens that leverage the decentralized and tamper-proof environments of blockchain networks to facilitate highly secure transactions. They are the native currencies of Web3 decentralized applications (dApps) and can also be used to pay for Web3 services and participate in Web3 governance. 
  
 Before blockchain technology, tokens were units of value that could be purchased and exchanged to pay for specific products and/or services, such as tokens for highway tolls or amusement park rides and games. In these earlier applications, tokens were useful to service providers because they allowed customers to pay upfront for services that they would consume in the future and because they facilitated transactions where exact change was required. 
  
 Tokens in Web3 applications are also units of value issued to Web3 content creators, but these units of value are digital, programmable, and have functions beyond exchange. In Web3, a token might be held as an investment in a protocol, project, or blockchain. It might have utility for that project or protocolâ€”for paying for a service or insuring a service, for example. It might also provide a gateway to participation in the governance of the protocol or project. 
 

### Smart Contracts and Decentralized Applications (dApps)

[Smart contracts](https://chain.link/education/smart-contracts) are tamper-proof programs on blockchains that facilitate automatic transactions by using conditional software logic such as, â€œ*if x is true, then execute y*.â€ Programmable smart contracts enable the creation of decentralized applications, or dApps, the cryptoeconomic protocols that bring Web3 to life and put it in the hands of users. 
  
 dApps are different from the applications (apps) that we are familiar with in the Web 2.0 world and the static HTML pages from the Web 1.0 world because they are not maintained by any single individual or organization but rather powered by the decentralized infrastructure of blockchain networks. These seemingly simple, decentralized programs can be used to create complex, automated systems such as [peer-to-peer financial services (DeFi)](https://chain.link/education/defi), [data-driven insurance products](https://chain.link/use-cases/insurance), [play-to-earn online games](https://chain.link/use-cases/nfts-and-blockchain-games), and more. 
 

### Oracles

To realize their full potential, smart contracts need to access and interact with data and systems outside of blockchain networks. [Oracles](https://chain.link/education/blockchain-oracles) are the entities that connect blockchains to real-world data and existing systems, and provide critical infrastructure for establishing a unified, interoperable Web3 ecosystem. 
  
 Chainlink oracle networks not only feed financial market data on-chain to power DeFi applications, but they also provide a wide range of secure off-chain computations such as [verifiable randomness](https://chain.link/chainlink-vrf) and [decentralized execution](https://blog.chain.link/smart-contract-automation/) to enable dynamic NFTs and highly automated dApps. Moreover, with the development of the [Cross-Chain Interoperability Protocol (CCIP)](https://blog.chain.link/introducing-the-cross-chain-interoperability-protocol-ccip/), oracle networks will help enable the fast-growing ecosystem of different blockchains and layer-2 scaling solutions to securely communicate with one another. 
  
 Oracles have emerged as an expansive layer of the Web3 stack, providing off-chain data and services to facilitate smart contract innovation, and cross-chain interoperability to help ensure seamless connectivity between different on-chain environments. Chainlinkâ€™s oracle infrastructure is also the gateway to Web3 for Web 2.0 backends, serving as an abstraction layer for traditional systems to interact with any private or public blockchain. Ultimately, oracles are the infrastructure that extends the power of decentralized computation and cryptographic guarantees to existing systems, bridging Web 2.0 and Web3. 
 

 
 

![Web3 is built with decentralized computing networks.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/pf2xXNtVs9zPFN7sfzMIq.png?height=1600&width=1529)

The renewed interest in NFTs has led to a Cambrian explosion of unique applications that leverage the property of non-fungibility in innovative ways, often with the goal of increasing efficiency in the transfer of asset ownership and reducing the need for intermediaries who siphon value away from creators and marketplaces. However, NFTs are still largely in their infancy, meaning there is a vast amount of opportunity for growth from innovative developers, creative artists, and traditional institutions wanting to bring distinct assets on-chain. 
 

## Web3 Applications

Web3 combines decentralization and interactivity to create a new model for the Internet where users can interact directly, without intermediaries. dApps allow users to access permissionless financial tools, trade cryptocurrencies in a peer-to-peer manner, receive parametric insurance payouts, buy and sell verifiably owned digital art through NFTs, play value-generating games, and a whole host of other activitiesâ€”all without the intervention of a central arbiter. 
  
 With this new structure, the proponents of Web3 hope to create a fairer, more open version of the Internet where parties can interact and transact directly. Currently, Web3 applications that leverage the three foundational technologiesâ€”blockchains, smart contracts, and decentralized oracle networksâ€”are already unlocking [use cases](https://blog.chain.link/smart-contract-use-cases/) that are redefining sectors as diverse as [real estate](https://blog.chain.link/blockchain-technology-real-estate/), education, [finance](https://chain.link/education/defi), gaming, and healthcare, and are set to have a transformational impact well beyond these domains. 
 

The technologies that comprise Web3 enable individuals to create and participate in financial protocols that offer unprecedented access, security, and transparencyâ€”a new economic landscape that is now widely known as [decentralized finance (DeFi)](https://chain.link/education/defi). 
  
 Unlike traditional financial services, DeFi protocols leverage the decentralized infrastructure of blockchains and the secure inputs of oracle networks to help users directly transact with one another in transparent and tamper-proof on-chain markets. [Decentralized money markets](https://blog.chain.link/decentralized-money-markets/) such as Aaveâ€”which now secures over $12B in smart contract value using Chainlink oraclesâ€”operate in a non-custodial manner and enable users to lend and borrow funds peer-to-peer. Money markets are a key mechanism for supporting a healthy economy. By decentralizing control and leveraging predefined smart contract logic, on-chain money markets help increase economic access, reduce single points of failure, and mitigate system risk and fractional reserve practices. Â  
  
 One great DeFi innovation is its [composable architecture](https://blog.chain.link/defis-permissionless-composability-is-supercharging-innovation/), which empowers developers to combine open-source protocols into more sophisticated financial instruments, such as no-loss savings games that use overcollateralized loan protocols, decentralized stablecoins, and interest-bearing tokens that put idle capital to work and unlock liquidity. 
  
 While the novel financial applications offered by DeFi are currently one of the most prominent aspects of Web3, the Web3 model extends far beyond financial transactions, encompassing every area of the Internet, from entertainment and social media to browser software. 
 

### NFTs, Gaming, and the Metaverse

[NFTs](https://chain.link/education/nfts), blockchain gaming, and the [metaverse](https://blog.chain.link/what-is-the-metaverse/) are currently emerging as key pillars of the Web3 ecosystem. NFTs offer verifiable ownership of digital assets, allowing digital goods to have a functional level of uniqueness similar to that of items in the real world. With NFTs, one digital item can now be differentiated from another even if they present the same way, similar to how two copies of the same book can be differentiated through their unique markings and evidence of specific wear-and-tear. 
  
 This has massive implications for digital art, metaverse applications, and video games. Currently, NFT projects such as [Bored Ape Yacht Club (BAYC)](https://boredapeyachtclub.com/#/) are popularizing NFTs and digital art, and blockchain games such as [Axie Infinity](https://axieinfinity.com/) are spearheading a paradigm shift in player economics in gaming. Underpinning this foundational transformation are blockchains, which operate as the underlying settlement layer, NFT smart contracts, which enable verifiable ownership of digital items, and decentralized oracles, which provide key services such as [verifiable randomness](https://docs.chain.link/docs/chainlink-vrf/), [smart contract automation](http://keepers.chain.link/), off-chain data, and more. 
 

### Parametric Insurance

One exciting use case emerging within the blockchain industry is decentralized [parametric insurance](https://blog.chain.link/blockchain-insurance/). Blockchain insurance projects such as [Arbol](https://www.arbolmarket.com/) and [Etherisc](https://etherisc.com/) are currently implementing novel implementations of frictionless and automated crop insurance, flight insurance, and more through a combination of smart contracts and off-chain data inputs facilitated by Chainlink Data Feeds. Letâ€™s walk through a quick example. 
  
 Imagine a farmer requires more than 20 inches of rain in a season for an adequate crop harvest. The farmer wants to hedge against the risk of a bad harvest through insurance. Normally, he would have to go through a lengthy process to receive funds and need to rely on a centralized insurance provider to verify the amount of rainfall. 
  
 However, in Web3, anyone in the world can permissionlessly take on a policy with just an Internet connection. With the blockchain-based crop insurance provided by Arbol, the insurance cost and payout terms are automatically determined based on pre-defined parameters, and payment is automated through an insurance smart contract based on weather data provided Chainlink. The insurance process becomes quick and painless, with a simple binary that determines whether the farmer receives insurance funds. Did an IoT sensor record less than 20 inches of rain that season? If yes, pay the farmer immediately. If no, donâ€™t pay the farmer. 
  
 This model has the ability to be expanded to areas such as [shipping](https://blog.chain.link/build-a-marine-insurance-smart-contract-with-chainlink/) and fire insurance, with blockchain-based parametric flight insurance already in operation. 
  
 

## Whatâ€™s Next for Web3

In his recent [Future of Chainlink presentation](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YShbzR7mlog), Chainlink Co-founder Sergey Nazarov explained the emerging megatrends of the Web3 ecosystem that have recently pierced the mainstream: â€œWhat you really see with the implementation of cryptographic guarantees in the Web3 world is a very specific set of applications, and some of these applications are called DeFi, some of them are called NFTs, some of them are called tokenized ownership, but these are the very early examples of cryptographic guarantees making their way into peopleâ€™s and industriesâ€™ daily operations.â€ 
 

![As people realize the power of cryptographic guarantees, theyâ€™ll move from centralized, probabilistic service providers to the trust-minimized services of Web3.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/-A2JyPMbt4YwwJLdiYEP6.png?height=900&width=1600)

 
 

Web3â€”a term that has become shorthand for a reimagined Internet experience powered by decentralized technologiesâ€”is already transforming how we interact online, from how we invest and exchange to how we play and express ourselves artistically. More and more users and institutions across the globe are waking up to the power of zero-trust interactions and cryptographically-backed agreements. While Web3 is still in its early stages, it has the potential to realize the ideals of hardwired transparency, reliability, and expediency the Internet was built to fulfill. â€œAt the end of the day,â€ Nazarov noted, â€œas Web3 approaches the speed, the efficiency, and the low cost of web systems, it has a guarantee that no Web 2.0 system can ever have, which is the trust minimization cryptographic guarantee.â€

title: dandelion on the go
body:
A long time ago, there was a wild goose who was injured and wanted to land on this treeless prairie, recuperate, and then go to a large army. Because in the past, they flew in the sky and rarely looked down. Therefore, for a long time, Although he passed by here, he didn't know that there were so many interesting people and interesting things in such a vast land. In this new place, he met many new friends, the chattering mole and the boasting hare. , Porcupines who are not good at speech, they quickly became close "comrades-in-arms". The happiest time for them is when night falls, outside the porcupine's residence, looking at the stars and talking about the distance, although the geese have been to many places, But in every place, he only knew a little bit, and he didn't know more details. One day, the porcupine said, Dayan, I have a friend who has admired you for a long time and wanted to get to know you, but he is not very convenient to move. Can I go see him sometime? Out of love, Dayan said, "Okay. In this way, something that changed the life of the wild goose happened. 

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/njUD0lhisxpd-7Wi2W-Qv.png?height=266&width=472)

Also when the sun went down, the wild goose, the mole, the hare, and the porcupine came to an inconspicuous place in the wilderness, it was him! Dandelion, Dandelion said to Dayan, Sister Dayan, I have a dream since I was a child. I want to be like my ancestors, to fly to the farthest place that I think I can reach. Can you tell me what the distance is like? Is it beautiful from afar? Dayan was at a loss for words, he didn't know how to start, he didn't know what this idiot-like question was referring to, in order to save face, Dayan began to talk about it, there are wonderful waterfronts, and there is an inexhaustible supply of them. , there is... After a nonsense, the mole fell asleep, the hare knitted the sweater in his hand, and only the porcupine was still listening to the geese's boast. On the way back, the porcupine said to Dayan: "Dayan, you and I have met once, and I want to ask you something, okay?" Dayan said, "Go ahead! I know that one day, you will leave here. , you will fly to your destination, I just want you to make some space for the dandelion, okay? Our family has been good friends for generations, I have witnessed the moment when they fly for their dreams, I want to make They fly higher and farther, even if it's only for a second, because you won't understand the power of the dandelion's dream on the grassland! Okay?" Dayan nodded, okay, I will!

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/7Lpym7bZVGhP02MKBxIuq.png?height=270&width=390)

The day has finally come, and the dandelion will choose to fly with the geese. On that day, moles, porcupines, and hares will all come to see them off. The geese are ready to take off with their blessings, entrustment, and nostalgia. The air blew on the dandelion, the wild goose took off, the porcupine, the mole, and the hare ran with him for a long time, until they turned into a small black spot in the distance, and flew for a long time, the dandelion looked at a valley in the distance, and the wild goose Said: "Goose, my distant place is not the fertile fertile field you mentioned. My ancestors told us that the distant place of dandelion is a barren valley. Our dream is to wait for one day to fill the valley with bright yellow flowers in spring. Autumn sends my pompom to the distance with the wind. The barren valley below is my future home. I want to spread my dreams here. Thank you for taking me on a ride. , I hope you can still think of me, goodbye..." At that moment, Dandelion fell in response, and in the wind, he ran his pompom all over the valley with the wind, the geese didn't stop, he knew his distance, yes Thereâ€¦â€¦

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Zo_spVH6YFKRtK2I2wZo-.png?height=266&width=420)

In the autumn of the second year, the geese took the road together and passed through the valley, where fluttering fluttered in the sky, he knew that it was the power of dreams, and he shed a tear, which was nostalgic for the dandelion...

title: Philosophy reflected from an egg
body:
An egg is fragile, and it is foolish to touch a stone with an egg.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/-OJtz-o_7KyIfdKBMJSI5.png?height=266&width=406)


â€‹â€‹
But if an egg falls from the 25th floor and someone sees it, Xin Yang, isn't it just an egg? It doesn't matter what will happen if we meet head-on? You will hear a "beep" sound, and in this "beep" sound, of course, there are eggs, but at the same time, there is the head that touched head-on.
â€‹â€‹
Some people have calculated that an egg weighing 30 grams will cause a swollen head if it falls from the 4th floor, the scalp will be damaged if it falls from the 8th floor, and the skull will be broken if it falls from the 18th floor. Falling from the 25th floor can cause death on the spot.
â€‹â€‹
A fragile egg becomes extremely powerful when it has a certain height and speed.
â€‹â€‹
So, don't underestimate an egg, and as an egg, don't underestimate yourself. A weak egg, with the corresponding conditions, can make a hard rock tremble with fear.
â€‹â€‹
Second, the professor said that there are two ways to break an egg. One way is to give it external force, and the other way is to let the egg break itself.
â€‹â€‹
An egg is sitting there, how can it break itself?

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/LNa-Zjo3QLTU9msRJdcwH.png?height=273&width=330)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/WSholT5Fner0SyRUFQ0uj.png?height=273&width=438)


â€‹â€‹
The professor said that under external force, the egg is broken, and the egg is going to be destroyed, but what if the egg breaks itself?
â€‹â€‹
The professor glanced at the students in the class and continued to say that if the egg smashes itself, it can only be the egg hatching itself, and a new life hatches in the eggshell - the chick, the chick grows continuously in the eggshell, When it grows to a certain level, the chick will peck the egg shell, break out of the shell, and break the original self-egg.
â€‹â€‹
If you donâ€™t want to let external forces break yourself, itâ€™s like an egg, constantly accumulating inner strength, breaking yourself, breaking through yourself, surpassing yourself in breaking yourself, realizing rebirth, and gaining new vitality and hope . the professor said.
â€‹â€‹
3\. When you are still an egg, why do you want to hit the stone hard?
â€‹â€‹
You know your fragility, you know you can't beat a hard rock, but why do you still touch it? Don't you know that under your fragile shell, there is a dream, a dream of life.
â€‹â€‹
For the dream, for the dream of that life, why can't you endure and wait?

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/-Wf4BCzDG1Hbpyb5Rs0Ba.png?height=266&width=436)


â€‹â€‹
When the dream of life emerges from its shell while waiting, when the life that emerges from the shell grows into a vigorous rooster, when you grow into a rooster, step on the stone and sing, and then look at the stone lying on the ground , is so silent, yet so inactive.
â€‹â€‹
No matter how fragile you are, as long as you still have a dream in your heart, waiting will change the fate of an egg.
â€‹â€‹
Fourth, it is impossible to let an egg stand upright.
â€‹â€‹
How to make an egg stand up? Tap the top of the egg lightly to break it, allowing the egg to stand up. But the egg that stands up like this is at the cost of maiming and destroying an egg. Cruel damage can make an egg stand up.
â€‹â€‹
How to make an egg stand up? Make a mold and put the eggs in the mold so the eggs can stand up. Moderate restraint allows the egg to stand up.
â€‹â€‹
How to make an egg stand up? Make a stand and place the egg on the stand so the egg will stand up. External support allows the egg to stand up.
â€‹â€‹
Letting an egg stand up is like letting a person's life stand up. What method do you choose to make your life stand up?
â€‹â€‹
5\. Once, a friend put an egg in my palm and asked me to hold it hard to see if I could hold the broken egg. But no matter how hard I try, I can't hold the egg in my hand.
â€‹â€‹
Usually, an egg can be broken with a single tap. Why is it that an egg in the palm of your hand cannot be broken even if you try your best to hold it?
â€‹â€‹
A friend said that we usually knock an egg and focus the target on a point of the egg. It seems that the force used is small, but when the target is concentrated, the force acting on the egg is also larger; Covering the whole egg, our grip strength is spread over the entire surface of the egg. It seems that the force used is large, but once the force is dispersed, the force acting on the egg is also smaller. Even thin layers of eggshells can't break through.
